content.title: Iliac Artery Aneurysm
content.definition: Iliac artery aneurysm is a focal dilation of the common, internal, or external iliac artery to >1.5x normal diameter (typically >1.5-1.8cm for common iliac), most commonly associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm but may occur in isolation.

epidemiology.internal_iliac: Less common but important for treatment planning

location_specific.common_iliac: Continuation of aortic disease, most common

clinical_presentation.local_symptoms: Pelvic/groin pain, lower extremity swelling (venous compression)

diagnosis.ct_angiography: Gold standard - sizing, anatomy, treatment planning

natural_history.rupture_risk: Increases with size (>3cm has significant risk)

options: Coil embolization of IIA + covered stent
endovascular.iia_management: Preserve at least one IIA if possible to prevent pelvic ischemia

open_surgical.indications: Not suitable for endovascular, young patients

complications: Colonic ischemia (rare if one IIA preserved)
internal_iliac_coverage.management: Preserve at least one IIA, embolize before stent coverage

content.statement: Iliac Artery Aneurysm is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Iliac that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

learning_objectives: Define iliac artery aneurysm and size thresholds
Explain internal iliac artery management during treatment
List complications of internal iliac artery coverage
clinical_pearls: 70-90% occur with concurrent AAA - always check
Preserve at least one internal iliac artery to prevent pelvic ischemia
Buttock claudication occurs in 30-50% after bilateral IIA occlusion
Embolize IIA before covered stent placement to prevent type II endoleak
